item.title: Land O'Lakes CEO Beth Ford, from the cornfield to the C-suite
item.description: Land O'Lakes CEO Beth Ford charts her career path, from her first job to becoming the first openly gay CEO at a Fortune 500 company in an interview with CNN's Boss Files.

item.title: Goldman Sachs slants research to help Democrats, top White House adviser says
item.description: Kevin Hassett, President Donald Trump's top economic adviser, suggested Goldman Sachs may be slanting its economic research to help Democrats ahead of the midterm elections.

item.title: China says it will never use its currency as a weapon in the trade war
item.description: Premier Li Keqiang said China "will never go down the path of stimulating exports by devaluing its currency."

item.title: The next big test for Elon Musk arrives this week
item.description: Read full story for latest details.

item.title: The next big test for Elon Musk arrives this week
item.description: Read full story for latest details.

item.title: CEOs are cashing in on the market boom
item.description: Corporate insiders at US companies have dumped $5.7 billion of stock this month, the highest in any September in the past decade, according to TrimTabs.

item.title: General Electric is in a sharp decline
item.description: Read full story for latest details.

item.title: Minimum wage since 1938
item.description: When the federal minimum wage first became law in 1938, it was 25 cents. Adjusted for inflation, that would be worth $4.19 today. Scroll over the chart to see historical minimum wage amounts, and their corresponding values in today's dollars.

item.title: Why investors aren't freaking out about inflation
item.description: Read full story for latest details.

item.title: Countries with higher wages than the U.S.
item.description: Some Republicans say high wages in the U.S. are hurting America's global competitiveness. See the countries where wages are even higher.

item.title: Corporate America, not banks, could cause the next recession
item.description: US companies have piled on a record-setting $6.3 trillion of debt.

item.title: Blind Brexit? Businesses fear even more uncertainty
item.description: The United Kingdom could leave the European Union with very little idea of what its trading relationship will be at the end of a transition period in 2020. That's a new nightmare for business.

item.title: Dow sets first record high since January
item.description: Read full story for latest details.

item.title: China strikes back by going after America's energy companies
item.description: Liquified natural gas is a fast-growing industry, and China's retaliatory tariffs will hurt.

item.title: Investors are starting to worry about the economy
item.description: One in four professional investors are bracing for global growth to slow in the next year, according to a Bank of America Merrill Lynch survey.

item.title: Executives on the front line worry about where the trade war goes next
item.description: Read full story for latest details.

item.title: What they're saying about the trade war at China's 'Davos'
item.description: As the US government steps up its trade offensive, business leaders in China say that Beijing is ready to dig in for a war of attrition.

item.title: Corporate America is spending more on buybacks than anything else
item.description: For the first time in a decade, Corporate America is steering more money into stock buybacks than investing in the future.

item.title: Lehman Brothers: When the financial crisis spun out of control
item.description: The implosion of Lehman Brothers -- and the mayhem it unleashed -- was the most terrifying moment for business and the US economy since the Great Depression.

item.title: These countries are most vulnerable to the emerging market storm
item.description: Rising interest rates, along with trade wars, have sparked a stampede out of Turkey, Argentina and other emerging markets.
